body:
### Problem

I try to write a function that process a visual selected block.
![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/53227593/b1eed6b9-4abb-467a-87f0-ae9695b197f7)

I write my script in python :

`

    command! -range=% CsvRightAlignNumbers python CsvRightAlignNumbers(<f-line1>,<f-line2>)

    python << EOS
    def CsvRightAlignNumbers(line1, line2):
        import os, os.path, vim
        x1 = int(vim.eval('col(".")'))
        x2 = int(vim.eval('col("v")'))
        y1 = int(line1)
        y2 = int(line2)
        print(f"({x1}, {y1}) ({x2}, {y2})")
    EOS
`
When I call this commant, i have the following result :
![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/53227593/ab182d56-ff97-43f1-9e16-437cd57b5042)

col(".") = col("v") = start of the visual block.
The help for col() says : 
		    v       In Visual mode: the start of the Visual area (the cursor is the end).  When not in Visual mode


When I write this in vimscript, it is even worse (??)

`

    command! -range=% CsvRightAlignNumbersTest <line1>,<line2>call s:CsvRightAlignNumbersTest()

    function! s:CsvRightAlignNumbersTest() range
        echo col('.')
        echo col('v')
        echo col('$')
    endfunction
`

result : 
![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/53227593/73c17288-7aec-45ca-89f3-8d208a128b72)
There, it's not even the column of the start or end of the visual block. It's 1.


### Steps to reproduce

copy paste the code in an .vim file in the plugin dir
Open vim
open a file in vim
visually select a block (the result is the same with <C-q>v or a simple v select)
execute the commands

CODE :
`

    command! -range=% CsvRightAlignNumbers python CsvRightAlignNumbers(<f-line1>,<f-line2>)
    command! -range=% CsvRightAlignNumbersTest <line1>,<line2>call s:CsvRightAlignNumbersTest()

    function! s:CsvRightAlignNumbersTest() range
        echo col('.')
        echo col('v')
        echo col('$')
    endfunction

    python << EOS
    def CsvRightAlignNumbers(line1, line2):
        import os, os.path, vim
        x1 = int(vim.eval('col(".")'))
        x2 = int(vim.eval('col("v")'))
        y1 = int(line1)
        y2 = int(line2)
        print(f"({x1}, {y1}) ({x2}, {y2})")
    EOS


`

### Expected behavior

I'd like the col(".") to act as mentionned in the help doc and return the column of the cursor (end of visual bloc)

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

0.8.1 (Build type: RelWithDebInfo)

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

I don't know (i can't install it, since V8, vim is detected as a virus on my machine)

### Operating system/version

Windows 10

### Terminal name/version

cmd

### $TERM environment variable

vtpcon

### Installation

From the .msi file

comment_data.body: You need to use `col("'<")` and `col("'>")`, because Visual mode has already ended when you execute the command.

Oups... Thanks for your answer. I've learned something new (did't think to use the command line notation in my scripts...)
The occasion to thank you... Neovim is my most used tool.
